@Commodore Stargazer I can't disagree with you on the fact that space technology is vastly under funded.  Investment in this area could effectively speed us towards a post scarcity society.  Unfortunately unless we deal with the climate crisis at hand we risk not making it as a species.  To get where we are we had to effectively deplete the bulk of the earths fossil fuel, and the thing that got us moving was coal.  If our entire technological infrastructure is brought to a near halt, because of global climate catastrophe, we will have to wait millions of years for coal to build back up to a beneficial degree.

@Matty Groves Well to pull from Things to Come (1936) It's either that or this, all the universe or nothingness.  Out across immensity to the stars, or we must snatch each little scrap of happiness and live and suffer and pass, mattering no more than all the other animals do or have done. 

Or as Larry Niven so succinctly said; "The dinosaurs became extinct because they didn't have a space program. And if we become extinct because we don't have a space program, it'll serve us right!"
@Commodore Stargazer Are you trying to make the case for advancing space travel technology faster, before the wheels totally come off here on Earth?

@Matty Groves "So, I have to ask you the same question a lot of people back home are asking about space these days...Is it worth it?  Should we just pull back, forget the whole thing as a bad idea...and take care of our own problems at home?"
"No we have to stay here. And there is a simple reason why.  Ask 10 different scientists about the environment, population control, genetics..and you'll get 10 different answers.  But there is one thing every scientist on the planet agrees on.  Whether it happens in 100 years or 1000 years or a million years, eventually our sun will grow cold and go out. ‚Äã@Commodore Stargazer We live in an ice age now.  Our geological period is the Quaternary, and is characterized by massive glaciation.  Vast ice sheets stretching from the Arctic all the way down to the Missouri River, through Siberia, much of Europe, and spreading out from all major mountain ranges.


Right now, we're in a brief interglacial phase, a relatively summery stretch in which the glaciers have retreated.  These interglacial periods are short lived.  The Quaternary Ice Age has lasted 2.5 million years so far.  It's 10,000 to 15,000-year warm patches are separated by glacial periods that last several times as long as.  The current respite is called the Holocene era, and it began around 11,000 years ago. 

So in short, that respite of 10,000 to 15,000 years... we're now beyond it's minimum and in that window where the warm patch could end!  Not a great position to be in when you add human caused climate change activity into the mix.

@ask the Etruscans I have been an active ecologist for over half a century. Where I live in the antipodes, we have just lost 5,000,000 acres to uncontrolled forest and scrub fires. I have watched my beautiful little river dry up due to over logging, clearing for cattle, deliberately lit fires, and especially lack of any real forest management. The carrying capacity of my river is around one one-hundredth of the original capacity just over one hundred years ago. Some holes have thirty feet of debris in them, and this has happened in the past fifty years. Once boats came twenty miles upriver from the sea, and now it is difficult to get a canoe down the same stretch. 
I am under one of the busiest air corridors in the southern hemisphere, and the air is sometimes green with aluminium nano-particulates from ordinary Jet A fuel combustion. I watch as the continuous lines of contrails descend and expand in diameter, as they condense virtually all of the atmospheric water vapour and drag it to lower altitudes. The UV radiation is so intense that plants are scorched, something only seen in the last few years. 
The bulk of the insect life, amphibian life and bird life has markedly diminished in the last ten years, and my plants have radiological damage. So, Mr. fake name, tell me that I am mistaken again. All of what I have described is directly connected to human activity solely. In my opinion, it is criminally negligent to deny anthropogenic climate change, even a monkey can see it. Apparently the moronic comments on this page have come about by deliberate obfuscation of the evidence, and you lot of ignoramuses have swallowed it hook, line and sinker. 
Undoubtedly the deep state swamp-elements have a climate change agenda, but they use much truth in order to disguise a big lie. They want climate change to get so bad that they can seize power and mark us like cattle with an RFID implant, and the ONLY way to avoid this looming catastrophe is to take care of the planet ourselves. We need to form green corps units to manage the forest fuel and convert it to humus, and we need to restore and rehabilitate the catchments of most of this beleaguered planet.
The ill informed and idiotic comments on this page are indicative of the near criminal insanity and total dumbing down of you lot of ostriches, so wake up or die!

The beginning of the video mentioned the San Antonio Food Bank so I wanted to share some information about why that photo of all the cars is troubling, The SA Food Bank is absolutely massive. In addition to the enormous warehouse for food storage, they have a 40 acre farm on site for vegetables, fruit, and dairy where I've volunteered. They also provided meals to students in the after-school program I worked for at another nonprofit and created a food pantry on my college campus. Basically, if you live in or around San Antonio you'll see how much impact this one organization has over a city of 1.5 million people PLUS the surrounding areas. So why is it troubling to see so many cars and know there's still not enough food to go around? Well, other orgs from around the country sent their staff to SA Foodbank to learn from their procedures but if our food bank is one of the best in the country and still doesn't have enough food to go around (especially when there are smaller orgs helping out too) then we have a real problem. We're seeing tens of thousands of people depend on SA Foodbank alone but if they can't even provide food to everyone then it speaks volumes about our society and the lack of government and corporate efforts to end hunger. TLDR; If we rely solely on nonprofits to fix hunger then we're never going to have enough for every family that needs it. Government and corporations need to be held accountable for food insecurity, too.

The elephant in the room is capitalism, which cannot possibly become sustainable, since it has to grow or perish.Capitalism is a cancer, a malignant tumour oft he economy. It is a heat engine driven by fossil carbon, and there is no alternative with a similar EROEI and robustness, so we have never developed any real alternatives to the Diesel engine for rural areas, for tractors, for trucks, for generators.
Without fossil fuels---and we will eventually run out if we don't stop using them--we don't know how to produce and distribute food on an industrial scale. We may need other types of heat engines that can run on a wide variety of fuels, not necessarily internal combustion engines but maybe also external ones, like steam turbines or Stirling engines. 
The future will be rough, we will need technology which is robust and versatile, and which is as modular as possible so that it can easily be taken apart and reassembled into something different. We will need farm machines that can run on anything, and which every small village can produce on its own in a tiny factory. We will have to deal with infrastructure breakdown due to decades of neglect and corruption and climate change, of course.

I'm not hearing what needs to be said here.  All I'm hearing are buzzwords.  The reason food rots on the field isn't because there's no infrastructure.  Its because nobody bought them.  A trucker isn't going to buy potatoes off a farmer to then give them away to a food bank.  Nor is a farmer going to donate his crop when doing so could cost them their farm.  Talking new tech ignores the fact that in times of crisis government should be organizing purchase and transport of food, and they didn't.  They didn't even think of it.  And that's the problem.
The only solution to food security in a post climate change world is to decentralize it.  Every home should be designed with food production in mind. It won't completely solve distribution but it provides individual households a buffer, so that distribution from larger farms can catch up.  It also reduces the amount of land needed to feed everyone significantly since a sizable portion of production is moved into urban and suburban landscapes.  Allowing nature and reforestation efforts to take over. At the end of the day climate change can't be solved with capitalism or innovation.  It needs to be solved by decentralization and self sufficiency.

LoL, this is funny.  The potatoes, the cars in the picture, and pandemic have nothing to do with climate change. The framing here is screwy.  She is right about GMOs, they are the way to solve a lot of problems, but there is a huge portion of the audience she is literally talking to that is anti-GMO.  These are your wealthy audience who will gladly pay 6-8 times more for "organic" products that use farming methods that produce too little to be nationally sustainable.  These are also the people who will pay 3 times more for a burger patty made out of plants, grown with bad farming practices and loaded with things the make them approximate the real thing, that are by every metric worse for you then the burger made out of beef.  Part of the farming revolution has always been the ability to make more out of less.  Less land, land fertilizer, less work, etc.  It's better to have real animals on the land, consuming the inedible parts of it, excreting nutrients the land needs, and then that animal can feed a person. This also has the ability to sequester huge amounts of carbon.  She also basically invoked the healthy user bias when it comes to those lab meats, but they are not market ready.  I know this because I can't buy them anywhere.  And if a piece of lab grown chicken is going to be more expensive than using real chicken, you have a real problem.  Innovation is interesting.  You can't just invent a new and better something and have it take off.  It has to appeal to people and you can't innovate via public policy, which is essentially what people want to do in this realm.

Climate change is not only understood to be "warming driven by human emissions of greenhouse gases, and the resulting large-scale shifts in weather patterns". this is a political and ideological statement, it is not science fact. 
Climate Change is understood by scientists to be an observed change in a scientifically recorded rolling thirty year average in either temperature or precipitation or the insolation index in any one locality. Climates throughout the world have always constantly changed and changes are not solely "driven by humans" and only relate to "warming" as stated by Wikipedia. Climates around the world will always continue to change regardless of human activity due to a combination of a plethora of continuously variable natural forcing.

climate change is normal but "rapid" climate change isnt. From a hot ball of fire to ice age to the optimal temperature that we know today is due to change in climate which took billions of years. But thanks to humans, climate change has been faster than ever. Earth has heated by 0.8¬∞C from the start of this century. Every decade has been warmer than the previous. According to IPCC, 1.5¬∞C average rise might put 20-30% species at risk of extinction. 2¬∞C average rise will harm almost everyone. *Average rise* means winter will be colder and summer will be hotter. The first kind of species to be affected by this change are warm blooded animals like Aves and Mammals. 750Billion tons of ice melts every year with the amount increasing every year. Thats 24,000 tons of water every freaking second, thats like the size of 10 olympic pools every darn second. Due to which the sea level has risen by 8cm in just 20years and at this pace it might rise by a meter by the end of 21st century. This is utmostfear for any island nations. 8 islands got submerged in 2017 alone, 3 in 2018. Countries like Tuvalu, Marshalls island, Maldives, Kiribati are at greatest risk. Maldives even held an underwater conference to highlight this issue. With increasing water level, the amount of CO2 trapped in ocean also increases thus increasing the acidity of water and making habitat of pisces much harsh. The increasing water level (as well as climate change especially from deserted area and area of high rainfalls) also contributes to immigration/refugees. The estimated number of climate change refugees is 250million by 2050. Rapid climate change has also contributed to harsh weathers/weather extremes and natural calamities. Recents examples include Amazon fire (altough was mostly highlighted due to political tensions between Brazil and USA), Australian bush fire 19/20, which occurs every year but this time it was the harshest and resulted in death of wildlife  more than any of the previous years, thanks to climate change aswell, Atlantic hurricane, Vietnam floods, etc.  The climate related disasters in the decade 2000-2010 was only 59 which jumped to 111 between 2010-2019 (2020 is still ongoing).

So, yes, climate change is inevitable but *rapid* climate change needs to be sedated.
Man-made or not is irrelevant since climate change will become an issue in the long run regardless if its done by us or not, so it's best we do something about it now rather than later

Unless you have a way of stopping the Methane Hydrate pouring out of the Kara Sea, the Laptev Sea, the East Siberian Sea and Chukchi Sea all along the East Siberian Artic Shelf you can forget attempting to save the Planet. This feedback loop now triggered has the potential to destroy all human life. Methane Hydrate is estimated to be 80 times more potent than Carbon Dioxide as a green house gas. There is currently an estimated 5 Gigatonnes in the atmosphere but 1,500 Gigatonnes in the sediments beneath the Artic Shelf; it is escaping and the writing is on the wall.

@michael Here's little chemistry for you. Assuming that the climate is not affected by an increase in CO2 emissions, there are still many consequences that could destroy the planet and us if we continue with our unsustainable amount of fossil fuel emissions:
An increase in CO2 in our atmosphere will result in the acidification of the world's bodies of water.
As we all know, water (H2O) makes up our lakes, rivers and oceans. We also naturally have some CO2 in our atmosphere. When they come into contact, they create carbonic acid, a weak acid:

H2O(l) + CO2(g) ---> H2CO3(aq)

Now normally this isnt a big deal, since the skeletons from dead fish in our bodies of water, when they decompose, emit carbonate( due to a reaction with the carbonic acid), a weak base. And since bases and acids cancel each other out, we return back to relatively pure, maybe slightly acidic (6.9 ish PH). Well what happens when we keep throwing CO2 into our atmosphere into our bodies of water? More aquatic life dies, more carbonate is formed to balance out the carbonic acid. Eventually we reach a threshold were there is no longer enough carbonate produced from the remains of fish to stabilise the PH of the water. Then the PH of the water continues to turn ever so acidic. But wait, there's more! Because water exists in many states of matter, we know that acidic water will eventually make its way into the clouds by means of evaporation. And when it rains... Boom! Acidic rain!
Now, a lesson in Biology:

All living things that exist in their habitats survived by living in a carefully balanced ecosystem. Plants use water the action of absorbing water to also sustain itself by pulling in nutrients to produce fruit, which are then consumed by herbivores, who are then consumed by carnivores, who then die and have their remains eaten by the tertiary consumers. Well, what happens if plants start to die off, or yield far less fruit because the water they absorb is the equivalent of a toxin for them and is destroying their cells? That problem is then passed on to the herbivore, who eats less, which is then passed on to the carnivore who eats more at first, then runs into problems, when the herbivore population plummets, etc. Now, onto us, humans. 

The human body has many means of maintaining homeostasis (maintaining adequate internal stability) the skin protects us from most bacteria among other things, our cells themselves have barriers that prevent certain things from entering and leaving, our blood has a relatively neutral PH of 7 to ensure that everything works properly. Now, imagine we started to drink slightly acidic water. Everything in our body would fall apart, cells would die, our DNA would break apart slowly, causing genetic problems, organs -one by one would fail. If you don't believe me just search up all my claims to fact check them.

This is just some of the ways that increased CO2 is killing us and the planet.

For me, 'catastrophic' means that it threatens organised human society. If this is going to be a catastrophe if we do nothing, then that means we should be suspending our whole economy to fix this problem before its too late. 

However, if it's not going to be a catastrophe, we don't need to do that. We can carry on as normal and feel more relaxed about the pace at which we need to fix the problem. 

So, you see how it matters? 

If you're interested, there is only one pole I found that asked climate scientists about how worried they were about manmade CC. 

It went something like this:
15% Not worried at all
45% moderately worried
40% very worried (catastrophic)

Now, when you see those numbers, it becomes clear that the debate in the scientific community is not about whether manmade CC is happening... it's about how concerning it is. 

So we need to stop saying 'the debate is over, there is no debate, the science is settled, 97%....'

The probelm with the "scientific method" employed by environmental science is that it measures only average temperature but doesnt conclusively identify a cause of change. The hypothesis is carbon emissions heat the earth. This fails to recognize the fact that 13000 years ago the earth was covered in ice. It warmed naturally. Not because of industrialized farming or carbon emissions. That heating mechanism is still unknown. They use ice cores to estimate average temperature on the scales of years.. But you can't use those cores to estimate daily highs and lows in temperature. As a result we think we know what weather was like in the past but in reality we only know AVERAGE temperatures on large time scales. We simply don't have the resolution necessary to make causal determinations.

I remember  in the 1990s a large percentage of scientists claimed that there will be no more ice caps by 2015.. then 2016.. Scientists don't say that anymore. Now its 2045. They were wrong then and are now. Is it because we are just smarter and more environmentally conscious human beings and thus have delayed the great melt? no. In fact we produce as a species MORE waste and carbon dioxide than ever before, thanks to global industrialization. Yet the lie continues. We have even observed a shrinking of the hole in the ozone! Did we do that? Or are natural forces at play?

We can barely predict the weather tomorrow afternoon. 50% chance of precipitation (lolz) What makes us think we can predict 20 years from now? And even then, what makes us think we could change it any observerable way within our lifetime even if we were correct. 

I am all for quality driven environmentalism. Lets get the plastic out of the ocean. Lets get the haze out of the air. But its sort of like exercise. It will make you feel better. Might even make you look better. But don't promise people they'll live longer. Because no one knows. You could be the fittest person on the planet and have a heart attack, or smoke every day and live into your 90s.

That's our planet. Lets focus on qualitative not quantitative.

The one-way-door thing works because shorter wavelengths of light pass easier through certain media (including CO_2) than longer wavelengths. The sun emits a wide spectrum, of which the longer wavelengths are partially "reflected" back into space by the atmosphere. The shorter ones reach the surface heating it up in the process. The surface, in turn, emits heat energy on the long wavelength spectrum. This long wavelength light is blocked by the greenhouse gasses from being radiated out into space.

I assume you already know that this figure comes from a study which analysed the text of all peer reviewed papers published in climate science over a period of several years.  The finding was that 97% of these papers explicitly expressed agreement with AGW (the view that human activity leading to increases in atmospheric greenhouse gases is the overwhelming driving force behind the current rise of global temperatures the past few decades) whereas 3% are either ambivalent (not sure), or explicitly disagree with AGW.  

I'd like to know your source for the claim that "many names are written upon supporting documents against their wishes".  I guess what you're imagining here is this: lots of scientific papers have multiple authors, and in some cases, author's names are included "against their wishes", since the don't agree with AGW.  In order for the 97% statistic to be seriously off target, let's say, as low as 50% or 60% or even 70% - this would have to have happened THOUSANDS of times (since there are tens of thousands of papers).

Trump is full of shit, as usual. There has been no "change in name." "global warming" refers to the long-term trend of a rising average global temperature. The vast majority of papers in climate science have are concerned with detailed parts of the picture that add to our understanding, like say, how is climate change affecting the spread of tropical diseases, agricultural pests and so on.  This is stuff we need to keep track of and predict as accurately as possible, for public health and economic reasons - but it's not about proving whether or not climate change is happening, because we already know that.

First, it's pure fantasy to attribute intentions or purposes to viruses; second, it's almost certainly impossible for a virus to kill "all humans".  A pandemic-based, long-term collapse of modern civilisation is just about possible (albeit, very improbable) - but  SARS-CoV-2 (which causes Covid-19) is nowhere near deadly enough to do that.  That would require need a very long, symptom-free but highly infectious incubation period, followed by a very high mortality rate (as imagined, for instance, in the novel "I am legend" and the movies it inspired).  From a virology point of view, fortunately, this is highly unlikely.

@Philosopher Aristotle Indeed, climate models are very sensitive to initial conditions. That's why we cannot predict the weather even a few days in the future accurately. This is why climate models are ran over and over again with slightly different initial conditions, who are then analyzed statistically. Long term climate models can be ran hundreds or thousands of times, all based on different future scenarios on human carbon emissions and various half-known climate variables. 

That smoothness problem is also not important for practical applications. Proving that won't help climate models.

‚Äã@Kattenelvis Most climate models are based on Navier‚ÄìStokes equations, which are extremely sensitive. When simulating Navier‚ÄìStokes equations, the relative error (machine epsilon), due to rounding in floating point arithmetic, drastically influence the outcome of climate models. This is the reason why the accuracy of weather predictions decreases rapidly over time. All climate models diverge over time and the only way to avoid divergence is to artificially adjust the parameters. Most climate models do not even take cloud formations into account, because of its complexity. Even basic properties of the solutions to Navier‚ÄìStokes have never been proven. Solving the Navier‚ÄìStokes existence and smoothness problem is one of the $1 million Millennium Prize problems. Anyone claiming that the science is settled, is willfully ignorant.

Consensus is actually exactly what science is. Scientific paradigms is what the experts believe are true based on their research. The current paradigm, which has been the case for 40 years, is that humans are releasing greenhouse gases which are warming the atmosphere.

Global warming for dummies:
CO2 is 0.04% of the atmosphere.
It means for every 100 molecules in the atmosphere there are 0,04 molecules of CO2
Now multiply both values by a 100. Then we get:
For every 10000 molecules in the atmosphere there are 4 molecules of CO2.
One of these 4 CO2 molecules was added by humans.
And for every 10000 molecules in the atmosphere only 1 CO2 molecule was because of humans.
Do you really think that this 1 CO2 molecule out of 10000 molecules is causing global warming? No.
You do not have to be scientist to understand this.

What makes radioactive material less harmful, the distribution over larger areas, does not work for CO2. That is distributed through the whole atmosphere and all oceans in any case.

@D Mars Of course, that happens, but CO2 is still a bigger problem, that is my point! 
Radioactive material is spread widely, but still in a limited area. Regarding the danger, it is not a problem how wide it gets spread, but where it is actually dangerous. There is often fear about radioactivity without significant actual harm.
When radioactive material distributes more, it is diluted. Measurement of radioactivity is extremely sensitive, so you can measure it even when it is completely harmless.
There is everywhere a little bit radiation, including where you are, but that is harmless, as you notice. It is called background radiation.
After the Chernobyl accident, more people died from the psychological effects like fear of radioactivity causing depression and then suicide, effects of constant stress and others, than from radioactivity.
That does not mean these deaths are not serious, but they are only little dependent on the actual radioactivity.
For example: A larger area of spreading of radioactive material sounds more dangerous, but makes it actually less harmful.

Concisely?  There is a science of climate change and the politics of climate change.  No one is suggesting changes to the economy or massive spending based on string theory.  No one is suggesting that due to the Big Bang we are going to have to all tighten our belts.  Science is about doubt and proof.  Politics is about "here's what we're all going to do now.."   Those who doubt are labeled "deniers", which is an attempt to demonize debate.
Hence, lots of downvotes.  And yes, it is very political.  One side is pushing for massive changes in how the world is operated, the other feels this is a made-up disaster with the objective being to create changes favorable to those pushing the argument. 
Or more concisely: "Here's a disaster, put us in charge of the solution".

We as individuals can't do anything. We can try to mitigate our own fossil fuel emissions by taking public transportation or riding the bike, wearing extra layers of clothing instead of turning on the heat in the winter, look at what we buy at the grocery store, buy more at local retailers - if they are open - instead of online ones, stuff like that. But that's not enough, not by a long shot. We need to continue FFF and Extinction Rebellion, show that only because there has been a pandemic, those aren't dead. And we have to exert pressure through protests and also strikes onto politicians to not return to the old ways but to build the economy back in a green way. And we have to back those up who are in favour of it or at least openly speak out for it. I'm German, I don't like our finance minister Olaf Scholz, he's definitely corrupt, but I refrain from attacking him since he said that he wants Germany to rebuild with basically our version of the Green New Deal. As many problems as I have with the SPD or the Green Party, I kinda have to support them even though their plans also don't go far enough, but they are our best hope to get the conservatives out of government and to keept the nationalists and libertarians out. And it's the same in other countries. Both direct action through protests and strikes but also electoral action are important. Climate change has to be one if not the only issue you base your vote on in the coming years.

A very distinct pattern has emerged repeatedly when policies favored by the anointed turn out to fail. This pattern typically has four stages: STAGE 1. THE ‚ÄúCRISIS‚Äù: Some situation exists, whose negative aspects the anointed propose to eliminate. Such a situation is routinely characterized as a ‚Äúcrisis,‚Äù even though all human situations have negative aspects, and even though evidence is seldom asked or given to show how the situation at hand is either uniquely bad or threatening to get worse. Sometimes the situation described as a ‚Äúcrisis‚Äù has in fact already been getting better for years. STAGE 2. THE ‚ÄúSOLUTION‚Äù: Policies to end the ‚Äúcrisis‚Äù are advocated by the anointed, who say that these policies will lead to beneficial result A. Critics say that these policies will lead to detrimental result Z. The anointed dismiss these latter claims as absurd and ‚Äúsimplistic,‚Äù if not dishonest. STAGE 3. THE RESULTS: The policies are instituted and lead to detrimental result Z. STAGE 4. THE RESPONSE: Those who attribute detrimental result Z to the policies instituted are dismissed as ‚Äúsimplistic‚Äù for ignoring the ‚Äúcomplexities‚Äù involved, as ‚Äúmany factors‚Äù went into determining the outcome. The burden of proof is put on the critics to demonstrate to a certainty that these policies alone were the only possible cause of the worsening that occurred. No burden of proof whatever is put on those who had so confidently predicted improvement. Indeed, it is often asserted that things would have been even worse, were it not for the wonderful programs that mitigated the inevitable damage from other factors.

I'm no climate change denier, far from it as I'm writing an essay explaining climate change to a friend, but Al Gore is an idiot. The reason why people refuse to accept the science behind climate change is very obvious yet no one talks about it ‚Äî It has been heavily politicized. 

Because of its record of being a political issue rather than a science issue, people have accused it of being a product of political corruption, hoax, scandals, or even a huge fraudulent attempt to submit free will to an oligarchy of power-hungry governments. The origins of its politicization mostly stem from the United Nations‚Äô ‚ÄúKyoto Protocol‚Äù plan to reduce industrial emissions from affluent countries like the United States, yet for some reason countries like China and India, which have worse environmental records than the US, were exempt from the plan. They tied climate change to successful countries rather than pollutive, yet it's easy to see that the most pollutive countries are actually underdeveloped countries or ones going through industrialization. In fact, the environment was at it's worst during its industrial revolution, but much of that pollution was cleaned up in the following decades and new inventions that were often not only less costly but also more environmentally friendly for the environment were created, thus pollution actually shrank in the years following industrialization in many countries for cost-efficient reasons. It really isn't hard to see that 90-95% of all plastic in the ocean actually comes from India, China, and Africa, not the west, according to recent studies. 

Another reason why climate change is rejected by many is that Al Gore was the figurehead/poster boy politician of climate change. He's devoted to politics, not science. He even was an advocate of the faulty Kyoto Protocol as well. If the reality of climate change was first spread by scientists like Stephen Hawking rather than a bunch of crooked politicians, the science of climatology wouldn‚Äôt have been rejected so much. The problem with most people who accept the reality of climate change is that they try to prove it with graphs or charts that show rising temperatures over time. They show pictures of ice caps melting or records of sea levels rising. They seem to often mention that some percentage of scientists agree with them. Climate change skeptics are rightfully skeptical when people do this. These charts/graphs/pictures often fail to properly show the correlation between rising levels of CO2 emissions and temperatures ‚Äî correlation and causation are debatable in that case. Furthermore, to say that a percentage of scientists agree with you means you have to have a whole number, as math teaches us, to determine that percent, and there is no credible existing list of a whole number of climatologists on record to be able to make such claims. No one can take these things seriously. Once again, this is mostly the result of politicians trying to act like scientists. To deal with the situation of climate change, it is best that society accepts its legitimacy first. To do that, we need to distance ourselves from these politicians and teach the real science behind why climate change exists. Even if Al Gore presents accurate and scientific proof of climate change, he's still a politician and he doesn't care for the environment. A rise of CO2 content in the atmosphere of 5 times what it is today (410 ppm.) to about the same level of CO2 during the Jurassic period (a little over 2,000 ppm. ) would not make the world uninhabitable for mankind. It would need to get well above 2,000 ppm or so to even start causing problems for non-plant life. The pitiful 300 or 500 ppm predicted would not even come close the levels seen at the time of the dinosaurs. Sure, it will get a little warmer and the storms might get a little stronger for a while until global temps equalize. 
The world‚Äôs bread baskets (the areas that produce food) will most likely move more toward the poles. Possibly turning Northern Siberia and parts of Canada into the next big bread baskets instead of the frozen waste lands they are today.... So things will change, but it will take hundreds of years, more than enough time for populations to move and for food production and industry to adapt.  Again, this end of the world scenarios (desertification drought and famine) being promoted is nothing but propaganda used by globalists to push their agenda..... Why would a world with the climate like that found during the Jurassic period be so bad? After all it did in fact produce the largest land animals and plants that ever lived.

Case in point‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.Farmers who run greenhouses pump extra CO2 into their grow rooms to increase production. If it makes their plants produce more food what do you think will happen if all the plants of the entire world get the same treatment?  

With more CO2 comes more plants, with more plants comes more O2 and water vapor (AKA more rain ) and the % of N (nitrogen) in the air drops, the air gets thicker and we all breath better....

P.S. How do you verify that your mathematical model of future climate change and its affects are correct? You simply compare it to the last time CO2 levels really did reach the predicted levels‚Ä¶ And when did that last happen? During the Jurassic, Triassic, and Cretaceous periods, a time of unparalleled plant and animal growth.

The next time some moron tries to tell you that a modest increase in atmospheric CO2 today will cause the end of the world tell them to go ask a dinosaur if it is true......

Now I am somewhat of a nature freak, I like hiking, I do my part to keep the earth clean, I ride my bike and I recycle. I'm also not 100% convinced that global warming is caused by humans, haven't their been piles and piles of geological studies that disprove the human influence and explain it due to the natural cycles the earth goes through over thousands of years? I'm not a geologist, nor do I know much about climate change, I believe it's important that we take better care of the earth but I am not 100% convinced it is man made, can someone tell me if I'm missing any important information? Or if this really is just a scientific sensation gone way out of whack because of the ethical and moral value involved?

For the record, I'm talking withing the confines of acadamia, I am not speaking in some conspiracy bubble that I made up in my head. I know many in the earth science department at my uni that say that it's not caused by humans. And I've also heard that some of the statistics often used to argue for man made climate change are false. I don't know enough about the specifics to know which statistics, but in some cases it has apparently happened.

Edit: for the record, I havent done much research on the subject, but I know most of you haven't either, this is why I am not rejecting or accepting a conclusion, because I simply do not know. I have asked here so someone can point me in the right direction of good journals or articles explaining the facts, without the emotional mumbo jumbo that gets in the way of the empiricism in scientific inquiry. I'm not a scientist for the record, just a curious bystander.

‚ÄúClimate change‚Äù traditionally was not human caused. Natural cycles have occurred for millions of years. However, since the industrial revolution, we have seen massive increases in greenhouse gases. There is a proven historical link between C02 and temperature increases. According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

For Science or possibly Military victories, the argument that building power plants is mandatory is fine.

Oddly the first version of CIV had a climate change system that actually had a more realistic impact.

I have a PhD in Physics. I've played Civilization from its first iteration.¬†Climate change was present in the game from the very start even from Civ 1. This iteration takes climate change to the next level although I am saddened to see unscientific things being taught to children who play this game. In the game, once CO2 is in the atmosphere it stays there forever.¬†There is no mention of a dynamical balance where CO2 is part of a cycle. The only way a player can remove CO2 is by carbon capture - which is a technology in the far future (and currently it does not seem like this technology will ever be feasible, in the game you're putting it back in a bottle). Conserving forests only helps in avoiding some of the penalties but it does not absorb CO2. Massive conservation and reforestation should. The game has the mechanics in place for it and this is more realistic. There is no CO2 penalty for bulldozing rainforests or clear cutting trees! Instead of presenting a magic pill option of carbon capture in a bottle, maybe kids need to learn about¬†the importance of forests and other ecosystems and their conservation. A few national parks on a few tiles  won't do it, this game could show all the data about forest and rainforest loss! Also if we're talking hypotheticals, the game could have included seeding the oceans with iron to simulate phytoplankton to absorb CO2 or seeding the upper atmosphere with sulphur for atmospheric dimming - as these are available now (although might have adverse effects of their own). The game also trashes nuclear plants are as once you build them they are a nightmare to upkeep and will inevitably blow up and pollute. The truth is nuclear is the only good option we have for the foreseeable future and it is possible to do it right (France). Yet the game shows wind and solar as the perfect solutions, you just install some in a tile and millions of people and their industry have enough energy in abundance. Unfortunately it does not work this way in real life ... I can recommend this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N-yALPEpV4w¬†

My final gripe with Civ6 gathering storm has less to do with climate and more about data: I always enjoyed all the data Civ games presented, all the ways you could order data find your most productive cities, your cities with most culture, etc, it was a fun way for a kid to learn to extract information from a lot of data, there were charts, graphs etc. In this new iteration? Not so much. You want to teach kids about climate change, ok. They have 3 power generation from coal and 2 oil used for fuel - why can't they just follow the links to find where? Why is there no data table showing the worst polluting cities and units? Why can't I see all the forest loss that occurred? It could even teach about the CO2 cycle - emitters and absorbers and show how the balance is broken. Data, exploring data was a key educational element in the game that is sorely missing now. All we have is the magic bottle that holds carbon and of course the giant death robot that can wade in the ocean. Sigh ...

Great video. I'm a geography teacher among other things and I'm glad to see other dimensions being explored in the Civilization games - things like religion were a really nice addition to Civilization IV, for instance. However, I'm always conscious with these things that game designers have to balance realism with fun and gameplay. Civ is already a very complicated game - I've only just got VI having skipped V (I own it, but I just didn't get into it) and I'm enjoying it, but there's a huge amount to learn even having sunk many hours into previous titles. (With IV, I never really did get the hang of the espionage mechanic even after such a lot of time spent with the game.) There comes a point where you have to make a game that works, and the more you add to it the more things there are to go wrong (and Civ's AI, while serviceable, isn't spectacular). Then there's also the fact that no one likes being penalised. Losing resources or whole cities isn't fun. Yes, it's realistic, and losing cities is part of the game, but unlike losing one in war to an enemy, losing one to climate change is completely outside of your control: there's nothing you can do to stop it, it's nothing to do with your skill. 


I can see myself playing a game and being pissed off when there's sea level rise and I lose some cities and could possibly lose the entire game, after several hours have been sunk into it. If I'm annoyed or frustrated, I'm not having fun, and therefore the point in playing a game is lost on me! I'll have to get the hang of the base game of VI first before I look at getting the expansion pack. We'll see.

I deleted my original comment about ocean acidification after i wrote it because it had very little to do with the original topic but it seems i was too slow and you managed to read it so ill adress that. I have no clue were on earth the ph of water could possibly oscillate by 4 through seasons nor how, but on average the ph of oceans (and lakes and rivers in a lesser degree) has been steadly decreasing as Co2 concentrations increases, this decrease in ph varies by region (the closest to river sources the smaller should be the decrease in ph) but on average is decreasing relatively fast. If i recall correctly below a ph of 7.8 it becomes impossible for organisms to fix calcium into their shells and they just dissolve . Its a common lab experiment to evaluate shell growth rate under different ph levels and there should be plenty of videos about it. Remember ph is logarithmic in nature and as such a very small change in its value can mean a very big difference in acidity (or alkalinity in this case).

San Carlos de Bariloche its in the province of Rio Negro, Argentina. Here in south Argentina there is a dry season during summer and a rainy season during winter, the snow that accumulates on the Andes mountains during winter melts and feeds the rivers during the dry summers sustaining the Andinos forests, by the time the snow is depleted the next winter arrives and the cicle repeats. But each year summer gets a little hotter, and rivers run out of water a couple of days earlier each time. Little by little different forests suddenly die as water runs out too early. This forests have evolved under this cicle and more rain wont be able to sustain them (rain rarely manages to reach past the mountain range). I know this is just a single anecdotal account of the effect of global warming on one single region of the world, but its were i live and were i¬¥ve grown so i thought i might as well share it.

There are many systems of positive feedback and negative feedback  involved in the CO2 cicle, climate change is a complex subject that shouldn¬¥t be trivialized,  yet because in countries like USA it has became a powerful political tool there is a lot of misinformation going around (both trying to minimize and inflate the subject). I wish the matter could be dealt with like the world dealt with the hole in the ozone layer, by addressing the problem and implementing viable solutions (i mention viable because many of the solutions i¬¥ve heard for dealing with global warming are just impossible to implement or completely noneffective in solving the issue).

Anyway i know YOUTUBEs comment section is not a good place to have this type of conversations and seriously discuss any topic (also i struggle against the language), so i thank you for been cordial and just sharing your sources and perspective honestly. I really shouldn't be writing this this late so a bid you goodbye and good night.

‚Äã@Nahuel Aizen The greening is well established mate, yet horribly underreported for such a big change. I get my date for this from here. https://www.nature.com/articles/nclimate3004. It's behind a paywall I know, but the conclusion is 14% greening in 30 years of which 70% attributable to an increase in CO2. Extrapolate those findings to the beginning of industrialization and we greened the Earth by about 25% only because of CO2. 

The carbon uptake of plants depends a lot on the CO2 concentration. More of it means it goes in quicker and they can be closed longer (meaning less water loss through the stomata). That's why the best greening is in arid areas, instead of desertification you have regreening of deserts (barring land overuse)

As for ocean acidification, it's totally fine. A station in Hawaii measured -0.04 pH since 1991. If you take into account that seasonal swings in some places are as much as 4 pH it looks to me like a whole lot nonsense that it's somehow a threat. And you do know it's calcium carbonate that calcifying species are using for their shells? More of that stuff just means it's easier for them to make shells. 

As for your forest, is that in California? Yeah I know California experienced drought, but more drought is not the worldwide trend. It seems highly anekdotal like the last summer was dry in the Netherlands. The worst drought in the US was the dust bowl and that's long ago. And you do know that higher temperatures also increase precipitation right? Well there's the offset of the more evaporation part for you. Not that the IPCC projections seem likely to me anyway because even though I acknowledge that CO2 warms the Earth I don't believe in the positive feedback that they work in their models to make the warming dangerous. Because if Earth's climate worked on a net positive feedback to warming life would be fried long before we came around, a net negative feedback therefore seems much more likely to me and a mild warming.

I don¬¥t know what you mean by "greened" given that worldwide the amount of forests and plant density in the last century have decreased. Im not suggesting this was caused by global warming, just that i can¬¥t seem to find why would you suggest the world has become "greener". 

Also, the biggest factor that determinates CO2 intake by plants its not CO2 concentration in the air but rather how much the plant¬¥s stomata remains open per day. Higher temperatures causes the stomata to remain closed for longer periods of time in order to preserve water which results in a smaller CO2 intake, and as such global warming has a negative impact in crop yield on average.

Anyway global warming is kind of a touchy subject for me. The city i live in, my hometown, has many ancient forests that are dependent on the rivers that come down from the mountains in order survive. Because the increase in temperature in the last decades many of this rivers now run out of water by the end of summer which has caused many of this beautiful forests to suddenly die out in a single season out of lack of water. My city¬¥s economy (San Carlos de Bariloche) depends on tourism so the disappearance of this forests do not only mean the destruction of many unique ecosystems and the local extinction of many wonderful animals and plants but also threatens livelihood of hundreds of thousands of people.

I definitely want a much more dangerous and severe climate change system, so I hope modders get to work on it. 

I understand why they went for such a toned down version, since rng in strategy games isn't usually something people are thrilled about, but I'd love more in this case. 

Let lakes and oasis's dry up over time. Let's  have more tiles flood on the coasts, and up coastal rivers, and let's have people not know when those tiles are going to flood until they unlock that as part of  some technology in like the medieval era or later. 

Let's make storms more deadly and more frequent, and have droughts last longer. I want a system of climate change that people will really want to avoid getting to those later stages because it will just ruin everyone's plans to some extent, possibly even forcing allies to fight one another for resources, or to prevent an ally from spilling so much co2 into the air.

Hell, if we could turn snow tiles into  tundra,  grassland into plains, plains into desert etc, that would also be amazingly brutal punishment for hitting those highest tiers of co2 emission (though that one might be a bad idea, considering the AI is too stupid to ever avoid hitting that point).

Right now you basically can ignore the system entirely, by just avoiding tiles with a high change of ending up submerged, and focusing only on the ones you can save, which is kind of unfortunate.

Maybe it's just from the small overview given here, but i feel like modern industrialisation is way to high up in the focus of this expansion ... I'm neither highly educated in climate science nor paleontology nor how intense the is influence of human activity is on a macro or micro scope. Anyway my point is, that from my knowledge that there are multiple cases where human civilization had devastating influence on the ecology of the world around them, like why did the bronze age dropped out of fashion or documentations of Romans mentioning the decline of nature in cultivated areas ... or Easter Islands. 

Destroying grown nature around is what makes human influence painful for the people more locally to the damage ... and this punish you first or alone for being  irresponsible and work natural resources to the ground.

Only with the industrialsation we come to the point where the actions of one part of the world can influence the planet as a whole ... but as we see in reality sadly/luckly not always where it's done, but mostly where it's already hard to come by ... for one or another reason.

Also what isn't shown in this video is how the player can deal with this ... is there even a way? Or is it meant to happen? Renaturation? Reforestation? nature-sanctuaries? 

What about Human healthcare? This was something that always limited population to accumulate in a single area and was highly effected by pollution and industrialsation. 

Another thing I miss is "natural" change of climate ... what about Ice-Ages? We have something like this in Endless Legend (maybe I bit to rough but it's something).

@Peter How so? In what fashion or form am I speaking nonsense? I merely mentioned one of the many ways scientist believe things might go.

The thing that happened to Venus is labelled "rampant greenhouse effects" and it is something that could happen to Earth if we are not careful.

It is the miniscule bacteria and algea life that are the main producers of oxygen on our planet. Guess where their main habitat is.

It's the ocean.

If the ocean turns too acidic, these lifeforms will start dying. They are extremely weak to temperature and chemical changes in the ocean.

Regarding the ocean level. There is set amount of water on the planet. There is a limit to how high the oceans can rise over a set amount of time. The current given projections for the end of this century are at 2.3-4 meters. 

In theory it could go up to 53m over the next 2000 years or so but that is exceedingly unlikely to occur faster than that. And due to temperature shifts and atmospheric changes it is unlikely that it would reach that level to begin with. By that point oceans would already be pretty close to boiling due to the incredible rise in temperature (minimum of 22¬∞C increase)

So by that point, the rising ocean level would be the least of our worry, considering the mass extinction that would be occurring by then.

Total War Atilla used climate change as an in game mechanic. Granted it was rather limited in its scope, only dealing with dropping fertility levels, and snow fall each year moving further and further south (this being a detriment to any army that doesn't have the no snow attrition ability.) I would say one game that did climate change really well as an in game mechanic is Endless Legend, which is basically a fantasy civ game... Winters get longer and longer, and cause more and more debuffs on your faction. If your game lasts long enough winters will eventually become "endless" since they will take so many turns to end.

Granted, the player doesn't contribute to this in any way, there is no co2 emissions or player interaction with how or when climate change effects start to take place. And there is no way for the player to really curb it, only survive it. I would say Civ 6 definitly did it better... which it better have, it is 5 years younger! If they released with mechanics comparable to a game from half a decade ago im pretty sure people would be reasonably upset. But then again, they did get rid of religions between civ 4 and 5 only adding them back in the expansion because so many people complained about it.

I'm not going to deny climate change or anything, in fact, I think the representation in Civ6 is pretty accurate. There's a marginal increase in bad weather, and a small percentage of land becomes submerged. Obviously, these are still bad things, and ideally it'd be a good thing to try and reverse them. I don't have any charts to pull or anything, but I feel like there's been this moving goalpost with global warming predictions that says there'll be some world-affecting natural disaster within ten years that gets set back within those ten years. So I've become pretty disillusioned with the whole thing, boy who cried wolf and all that.

If someone would care to explain this to me, I'm all ears.

I can totally understand where you're coming from. There's a tendency in the mainstream media to over-emphasise the most dramatic predictions and ignore uncertainty.

If you're interested in getting a better understanding, and don't mind a little bit of reading, I'd advise having a skim of the official summary reports by the IPCC (setting aside an hour will be enough to make you more knolwedgable than 95% of internet dwellers!!!). You'll immediately notice that the language is far more measured than soundbites from TV, reflecting peer review by dozens of different authors. I think a key part of this is recognising that there's a big difference in future scenarios, e.g. 1.5 degrees of warming vs. 3 degrees and how long this takes to occur, as well as recognising the limitations of thier forecasting methodology.  As far back as I'm aware, the IPCC have been highly consistent in their findings as opposed to 'moving the goalposts'. 

Latest full published report:  https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar5/syr/
Latest chapter on potential impacts:  https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/2/2019/02/SR15_Chapter3_Low_Res.pdf

All that said, my understanding is that a 'marginal increase in bad weather' is an understatement. The biggest impacts for humans aren't day-to-day variations in temperature and rainfall, but that extreme events such as floods, droughts and hurricanes become more frequent and more severe. So what was previously 'the worst storm in one hundred years' now occurs every ten years, for example. Also worth bearing in mind that Western countries such as the US can probably deal with slightly more regular and severe natural distasters, both through investing in preparation and crisis response. It's very different for second and third world countries where property insurance and emergency healthcare aren't available :( :( :(

I'm going with the judgement of Richard Lindzen regarding the IPCC process over yours. I worked in biomass energy as a consultant/engineer and the subject kept my interest. I have  seen too many shady things in this field over the years to have any confidence in the morality of the leading people in the IPCC. The climate gate emails gave clarity as you should understand.

Ah, I can see what's happened here! You've got the wrong end of the stick. The 'leading document' is a summary of all the other elements of the report - working groups I-III - which are exclusively written by thousands of scientists based on peer-reviewed research (the peer review process for the working groups takes over six months, in three separate rounds). The heads of these working groups then summarise their findings into the summary for policy makers. That summary then goes through another round of review based on comments from governments (which invariably tends to make the reports too conservative in their conclusions) before going through a final review by scientists to make sure nothing in the final document is misleading or incorrect. So the IPCC process is entirely scientific, but with a single step at the end involving international governments. The conclusions of the report have been through arguably the most rigorous peer review process in all of science, and can therefore be viewed as completely correct.

The leading document in the IPCC is the summary for policy makers, not a scientific document.The I in IPCC stands for Intergovernmental. IPCC has not produced any falsifiable hypthesis. It is not science what they do. Sorry to have to break it to you.

"Will civilizations have made the same decisions if they knew beforehand the consequences of increasing CO2?"  
  
Very interesting question, and that depends on a lot of things, but arguably the most important factor would be whether or not modern capitalism also existed. In a market economy owned by those that own large amounts of land and wealth, it might not be likely that those powerful wealthy individuals would slow down on production, as that is needed to dominate a marketplace. Communal ownership, on the other-hand, incentivizes more thoughtful allocations of resources, and to consider long-term non-market consequences.

@‚Äã Wytze van der Veer  You know, in my country we tried that (or at least the Communist Party was claiming so). Thanks to the Party my country (Poland) passed requirements of Kyoto protocol. Yup... The baseline emission period was in the last days of planned economy when we had huge amount of mostly useless heavy and chemical industry. Under capitalism such industry went mostly bankrupt, as "wasteful" started to mean "unprofitable". After a while economy readjusted towards production of consumer goods and services, so CO2 emission went drastically down in comparison to communist times.

Conventional nuclear fuels are mined from relatively low-source minerals and need to be refined and it's that process (which can be quite energy intensive) that puts some nuance in the statement that nuclear power is carbon neutral. Not-in-my-back-yard (NIMBY) is definitely a stance a lot of anti-nuclear folk take but there are other issues with nuclear power which are more to do with technical aspects.

This means your education was 'successful.' 

Greenland is not "melting"  In fact it accumulates far more ice annually than its land surface can support.  The result is that the mountains of ice accumulate in the center of Greenland continue to grow until a dynamic equilibrium is established between plasticized glacial ice pancaking outwards until there is no more land to support the mass.   This ice either falls into a warmer sea and melts near the shore or is ripped away by sea currents to melt elsewhere.    

This flow rate is not uniform since the time it takes for glacial ice to pancake out from the center of the land mass to the shore is measured in many centuries and governed by glaciation rates that occurred long ago.    

To the best guess that current measurement techniques offer (and they are guesses)  Greenland put on a little additional ice (only a few hundred billion tons)  in the 2016-2017 and 2017-2018  ice seasons and is on track to lose an equally tiny bit of ice in the 2018-2019 Ice season.    This is 'weather' not 'climate'

Yes, the sun is cyclical, but the composition of the earth's atmosphere is important.

Think of it like this.  The earth's atmosphere is like the "canvas" that the sun's energy gets "painted" upon.

If that atmosphere has "normal" levels of greenhouse gases in it, the amount of energy from the sun, being whatever it is at the time, will cross the distance between earth and sun and the climate will be "normal".

Now imagine you increase the percentage of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, the amount of energy from the sun, being whatever it is at the time, will cross the distance between earth and sun and the climate will be warmer than normal.

Increase the percentage of greenhouses gases even more in the atmosphere, the amount of energy from the sun, being whatever it is at the time, will cross the distance between earth and sun and the climate will be even more warm than normal.

@andrew30 uhh, Americas emissions per capita are far from the highest in the world you moron. Luxembourg, Belgium, Singapore, Kuwait, Bahrain, the Netherland Antilles, U.A.E., Trinidad and Tobago, Qatar, and Australia for example have higher emissions per capita than America. Also, most of Europe is above the global average for CO2 emissions, and hasn't made much, if any progress since the Paris climate agreement. Even China's CO2 emissions per capita are lower than almost every European country. Furthermore, you are comparing dense countries where travel is short, and renewables are more feasible on a national scale to the third largest country in the world both in land coverage and population (the United States is the size of Europe but half the population). The space between cities aren't as dense, making walking or biking unfeasible for anyone outside the inner city, the space between cities is greater, meaning high-speed railways and public transport isn't as feasible nor practical, meaning cars take their place. However, electric cars are too expensive for most people (Europe included), so guess what. People are forced to use hydrocarbon fueled cars. So no matter what, that won't change unless electric cars become cheaper than regular cars or unless the U.S. government relocates everyone into denser patches. 

Renewables aren't as practical either, as they are less efficient in less dense regions. Also, when it comes to solar (the cleanest renewable and the highest potential renewable in that it can be implemented in most areas efficiently) we have no way of storing the energy.

When it comes to wind power, it also has it's downfalls. The wind is strongest late at night and early in the morning on average, but energy demand is highest between 6 a.m. to 10 p.m., and peaks at 6 p.m., when wind is weaker. Meaning you once again have to store energy created at night. Wind power is also limited in where it can be implemented, many of the areas it can be implemented aren't highly populated. 

When it comes to thermal energy, it is consistent, but it can only be implemented in an extremely select number of areas. Only 3 are considerably populated, these being Western California, the Pacific Northwest, and Anchorage.

Hydropower has high potential; however, there are very few places left in the U.S. where hydropower station and dams can be built and supply considerable energy. So it is basically limited in it's extent. It also causes it's own damages. This being large amounts of methane production (artificial lakes are one of the largest producers of methane today), CO2 production (the Hoover dam produced roughly 6,600,000 tons of CO2 during it's construction, even more sense then), they flood massive amounts of land, reduce the silt in water, harm species (dams in China have been one of the largest causes of extinction in China, and dams in the west have threatened native fish soecies greatly), and after some time silt renders dams useless.

@Starley Shelton Reconsider the "unusually stable climate period" of the last 11,000 years.  Many contend that the stable climate period ALLOWED humans to develop the technology to farm instead of continuing the hunter-gatherer life.  
I think there has been a feedback from human activities since the end of the last glacial period, about 11-12 thousand years, which is what stabilized the climate.   Humans may well have altered the climate for this whole period.  Industrial activity, which is generally considered to have existed since 1750, has vastly increased the scale and shortened the time that it takes for profound changes in climate and habitat to affect the biosphere.  CO2 and atmospheric particulates and aerosols increased enormously during the build up for WW2.  The war also released a lot of smoke and particulates.  Post-war rebuilding and industrialization pumped a lot of this stuff into the atmosphere.  The rapid increase in temperatures (GAST) began in the mid 1970s as clean air acts world wide began to attenuate the release of atmosphere-altering gases, particulates and aerosols.  The "aerosol parasol" has been keeping the biosphere from heating as much as it would otherwise have.  The removal of much of the pollutants from coal combustion, due to decreased coal consumption and the addition of scrubbers to the exhaust from those facilities that still burn coal have removed much of the parasol, too.  This is also driving the temperatures higher, quicker.

Viral FACTS:
Viruses cannot enter through the skin or eyes. Such vectors do not work because the mucus membranes and the immune system discard small amounts of foreign proteins such as viruses.
Viruses cannot enter through wounds because we bleed outwardly, not inwardly.
Viruses do not 'exist' outside of petri-dish solutions or a living body.
Viruses cannot function without a host cell that manufactures them and encodes them, and viruses cannot replicate without a host cell.
Viruses do not 'infect' or 'invade' cells. They are not alive to do so in the first place. Viruses almost never dissolve living tissue, unless in specific circumstances such as polio and degenerative nervous system diseases where metal toxicity is present.
Viruses' primary function is to dissolve dead matter.
Cells produce different viral strains depending on the condition of the tissue involved.
There are 320,000 viral strains inherent to the human body, and each cell contains the viral protein makeup to manufacture each strain when the body calls for it.
Viruses are sequenced/encoded by blood cells via RNA/DNA to break down specific dead and dying tissue and waste. Viruses are very specific protein structures.
Coughing, sneezing, and spitting is not a vector for the transmission of viruses. Saliva and mucus membranes break down any such particles. Skin is not a vector either because viruses cannot cross dead skin layers.
The only way to get a virus outside of natural means is via direct injection (vaccine) or blood transfusions of a patient who has a virus. However, in such cases, the body only analyzes it as foreign tissue that must be eliminated. Since the virus did not originate within the bodily host, that body does not know the time and place that the virus will be active nor does it have the key to decode it (RNA or DNA encoded by the cell) and cannot find the time of its activity. As such, it is analyzed as a foreign substance that must be eliminated. 

Viruses are a result of internal toxicity caused by the environment. Viruses are cyclical in animals. Viruses feed upon waste products in the blood and tissue. Throughout the year, upon season and climatic/temperature changes, the body will dump mass amounts of toxins into the blood for removal. Some of these toxins are so toxic in nature, such as mercury, formaldehyde, and other chemical byproducts, that living microbes cannot feed upon and eliminate them without dying. Non-living proteins are then manufactured by each cell in the corresponding location of the body where this cleansing is necessary. Those toxic substances are disassembled and broken down by viruses so that the body can eliminate them, restoring homeostasis.
Viruses cannot cross-species ie; from animal to mankind. It is impossible for humans to develop animal flus‚ÄîA. Because viruses are not contagious, and, B. Because animal RNA/DNA is not compatible with human RNA/DNA. The only way animal tissue can be observed in the blood is through injection of animal tissues, which make their way to the blood, bypassing the digestive tract.

Here is a list of 13
 things you should do to help:
1. Stop eating meat.
2.Plant trees.
3. Switch off electrical appliances at least for 30 minutes for a day.
4. Use Paper until it is unusable. 
5. Stop encroachments.
6. Don't throw pet animals especially dog out of home, this will cause the animals to search for a home and will cause problems for other animals as humans are cutting forests down.
7.Afforestation.
8. Stop smoking.
9. Don't burn garbage. 
10. Use more public transportation. 
11. Use more cycles and see if you can use solar panels for electricity.
12. Don't waster water as we have only 0.04 % freshwater leftover on the surface the other percentage is present as groundwater and in polar glaciers.
13. Just do what you can to help, which everyone can do.

So here's how that works, in a nutshell:

1) We burn lots of stuff: coal, gasoline, wood, etc for heat energy
2) The burning releases huge amounts of CO2 into the air
3) CO2 in the air makes it harder for heat to escape from the Earth (as IR radiation) and so the atmosphere heats up some compared to before, and the CO2 has "staying power" there
4) a hotter atmosphere helps more H20 get there which also similarly leads to even more heating
5) all that changes air flow, temperatures and large scale rain/snow patterns on yearly average, for each season
6) you get more drought in some places and more rain in others, on average, plus more extremes in temperatures 
7) with more drought, fires that normally and naturally occur become more extreme in frequency and extent (they don't die out as easily)

For the people that have trouble understanding what Bio-climatologist Williams was pointing to (first speaking guest). Is that there is a clear indication that much warmer temperatures are connected to more severe forest fires. The most simple explanation, is that if you put humid (wet) pieces of wood into the oven, the more you increase the temperature (dialing up the oven),  the more that water evaporates from the wood and it gets dryer. The more dry wood you have, the more pieces catch fire and can burn longer, just like a campfire or fireplace but then much, much bigger. Cheers.
