@Billsbob Nature doesn't care about your political opinions. Positive feedback loops have been a thing ever since the Earth's trajectory around the Sun. Where normally these are activated by moving away from a glacial period due to the increased sunlight our Earth receives, which naturally warms up the atmosphere and activates positive feedback loops. One example is the thawing of permafrost which releases CH4 (Methane), which traps heat like it does now and results in warming up the atmosphere even more, thus thawing more permafrost and the loop is established. The issue now though, is that we with our human contribution not only have done what nature normally takes thousands of years to do, we accelerate this process while it's ongoing. So dozens of natural feedback loops have already been activated.

Fossil charcoal indicates that wildfires began soon after the appearance of terrestrial plants 420 million years ago. Wildfire's occurrence throughout the history of terrestrial life invites conjecture that fire must have had pronounced evolutionary effects on most ecosystems' flora and fauna. Earth is an intrinsically flammable planet owing to its cover of carbon-rich vegetation, seasonally dry climates, atmospheric oxygen, and widespread lightning and volcanic ignitions.

Strategies for wildfire prevention, detection, control and suppression have varied over the years. One common and inexpensive technique is *controlled burning* : *intentionally igniting smaller fires to minimize the amount of flammable material available for a potential wildfire.* Vegetation may be burned periodically to maintain high species diversity and limit the accumulation of plants and other debris that may serve as fuel.

Addressing your claim about climate models, it is false. Models often give great predictions (see source below) but as it is impossible to observe and compute every molecule and every interaction with the complex physical equations that models use, they are approximations. One of the ways we try to combat this is through the use of ensemble models. These ensemble models are initialized with slightly different initial conditions and slightly different parameters to address uncertainty. These produce a range of results which are either averaged or used in a percentage of seeing a certain outcome. Now, the claim that we have a plastics problem is 100% correct. The Sun cycles every 11 Years...during which solar activity increases and ebbs in a somewhat predictable fashion. The sun's temper varies on an 11-year cycle, typically taking about 5 1/2 years to move from the quieter period of solar minimum, to the more turbulent solar maximum. Sunspots sometimes erupt into powerful solar storms that shoot streams of charged particles into space, occasionally in the direction of Earth. Earth travels around the Sun. One complete orbit takes 365.256 days. During which time Earth has traveled 584 million miles. The diameter of the Sun is about 864,938 miles. If the Earth were hollow, about 50 moons would fit inside. Our Sun is so large that about 1,300,000 planet Earths can fit inside of it. üëçüôÇ

@isac murdanhe  ...because the Moon spins on its axis once every 27.3 days. 27 days, 7 hours and 43 minutes. The Moon completes between 12 and 13 cycles of lunar phases in 1 year. The lunar phase cycle (from new Moon to new Moon) is 29.5 days. The tides are one of the most important ways that the Moon affects life on Earth. They are the result of the fact that the Moon's gravitational pull does not affect all parts of Earth equally. The lunar gravity exerts a stronger pull on the parts of Earth that are closer to the Moon. Low tides and high tides are the results of gravitational pull by the moon. The moon's gravitational pull is called the tidal force. The tidal force causes Earth‚Äîand its water‚Äîto bulge out on the side closest to the moon and the side farthest from the moon. These bulges of water are high tides. The tides around the equator are higher during both a new moon and a full moon (spring tide). This proves the earth is not a flat earth. üëçüåù

@LastBref
What "other surveys"? The other 97% consensus papers where not surveys.

Bray and von Storch were apparently disappointed that their surveys refuted the 97% consensus. You seem disappointed too.

Bray and Storch even went out of their way to avoid the most important question: *How much of observed warming has been caused by human CO2 emissions*. Instead they only ask about _anthropogenic_ climate change, which includes a whole host of factors that are irrelevant to the IPCC agenda. They also mix future and past, when the important evidence is whether past warming has occurred as predicted. Future warming is pure speculation.

There was a survey, I forget by whom, that actually asked for a percentage of recent observed warming that was caused by human CO2. The results were difficult to interpret since many scientists said >100%. This is apparently because they recognized that expected warming had not occurred, and since the anthropogenic contribution must be greater than zero (something skeptics also believe), greater natural forces must have counteracted it.

A telling section of the Bray survey asked about the reliability of the computer models upon which the predictions of catastrophic warming are based. Only a¬† tiny minority of climate scientists think the models will do a very good job of predicting temperatures even 50 years from now. Inconvenient.

@George Applegate¬†I researched the study you cited. And it turns out that the authors aren't very happy with the way climate deniers have been misrepresenting their survey. Here is Dennis Bray's response:
http://klimazwiebel.blogspot.com/2014/06/misrepresentation-of-bray-and-von.html

^He points out the various ways in which this survey has been misrepresented by climate skeptics. You're trying to cherry-pick a survey to support your argument while ignoring all other surveys, without realizing that the study you're cherry-picking doesn't support your argument either.

Here's what the survey actually finds:
"87.4% of respondents are to some extent convinced that most of recent or near future climate change is, or will be, the result of anthropogenic causes."

^And look at the way the question is phrased: "most of."  And even bigger percentage would agree that it's happening and humans are contributing, even if they don't believe humans account for "most of" climate change.

@LastBref
Indeed, listen to what climate scientists *_say_* not what non-climate scientists suppose they think. Andregg (biology professor) did NOT ask climate scientists what they thought. He counted scientists who signed off on a general IPCC statement, and then _inferred_ that those all believe that human CO2 emissions are the primary driver of climate. He then compared that number to his estimation of the number published climate skeptics. That is very far from surveying climate scientists.

Climate scientists don't get to participate in the IPCC unless they support anthropogenic climate change. The IPCC is not a scientific body, but a branch of the UN whose stated purpose is to report on any evidence that human GHG emissions are causing climate change. That's how they define _climate change._

I might as well take the number of Imans and compare that to the number of religious leaders who publicly oppose Islam, and then claim that 97% of religious leaders are Muslim.

Dennis Bray (emeritus professor at Cambridge) and Hans von Storch (professor at University of Hamburg) actually surveyed climate scientists. Theirs are the only comprehensive surveys. Scientists have already dealt with why all of the above you mentioned are not the significant most probable causes. Let me deal with them each of them :

1. Variation in earth‚Äôs orbit (Milankovitch cycles) - The tilt of the Earth‚Äôs axis and the shape of its orbit around the Sun vary slowly over tens of thousands of years. This changes climate by changing the seasonal and latitudinal distribution of incoming solar energy at Earth's surface. During the last few thousand years, this phenomenon contributed to a slow cooling trend at high latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere during summer, a trend that was reversed by greenhouse-gas-induced warming during the 20th century [1]. Orbital cycles favorable for glaciation are not expected within the next 50,000 years [2].¬†

Sources -
[1] - http://science.sciencemag.org/content/325/5945/1236.full
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2527990/
[2] - http://science.sciencemag.org/content/297/5585/1287

2. Solar Activity - Since 1978, solar irradiance has been measured by satellites. These measurements indicate that the Sun's radiative output has not increased since then, so the warming that occurred in the past 40 years cannot be attributed to an increase in solar energy reaching the Earth. Climate models have been used to examine the role of the Sun in recent climate change. Models are unable to reproduce the rapid warming observed in recent decades when only taking into account variations in solar output and volcanic activity. Models are, however, able to simulate the observed 20th century changes in temperature when they include all of the most important external forcings, consisting of both human influences and natural forcings [1]. Another line of evidence for the Sun's non-attributability is the differing temperature changes at different levels in the Earth's atmosphere. According to basic physical principles, the greenhouse effect produces warming of the lower atmosphere (the troposphere), but cooling of the upper atmosphere (the stratosphere). If solar variations were responsible for the observed warming, warming of both the troposphere and the stratosphere would be expected [2].

Sources -¬†
[1] - http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-9-2.html
[2] -http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2008JD010421/abstract;jsessionid=C93F0536879EC2E14602D4633F819C39.f03t02

You get my point. Please read the scientific journals and all these rudimentary queries are answered. Don‚Äôt try and silence people like me and everybody else who wants to follow the evidence and act on the basis of that.

Areas affected by the Little Ice Age suggested largely-independent regional climate changes rather than a globally-synchronous increased glaciation. At most, there was modest cooling of the¬†Northern Hemisphere¬†during the period. This is not global. So you are wrong. Comparing this period with current global warming is an equivocation fallacy. 

And let's look at the causes. Several causes have been proposed:¬†cyclical lows in solar radiation, heightened¬†volcanic activity, changes in the¬†ocean circulation, variations in¬†Earth's orbit¬†and¬†axial tilt¬†(orbital forcing), inherent variability in global climate, and decreases in the human population. For this current warming period that's happening now, we have found the most significant cause, CO2.

Climatic¬†Proxy¬†records show peak warmth occurred at different times for different regions, indicating that the Medieval Warm Period was not a globally uniform event. This is not global, so you're wrong that the medieval warm period is connected to today's global warming.

The 97% figure wasn't pulled out of thin air, it comes from the National Academy of Sciences: "This study compiled a list of 1,372 climate scientists, and then looked at those who are "actively publishing" in the science of climate. They categorized the scientists as either "convinced" or "unconvinced" by the evidence. The results were that 97% of actively publishing climate scientists are convinced by the evidence of anthropogenic climate change. They also found that those scientists that were unconvinced had significantly fewer publications (in any science) than those that were convinced. Sorry, but you're mistaken about this. Grasslands have roots that are constantly growing and sequestering carbon, some as deep as 18 feet into the ground. Plant growth is stimulated by the animals that feed on it, which also provide fertilizer that increases the number of worms and dung beetles that make the soil rich and porous so water can infiltrate and be held there. It's good to have some trees, of course, as they provide shade for the animals, and having silvopasture is great, especially for pigs, but it can't apply to an entire farm. And trees eventually must die or be thinned (that's why there used to be all those beavers everywhere), which means the carbon in them is released either through fire or the gradual decomposition that happens over time. Of course, trees are valuable for lumber, too, a renewable resource. Cows grazed on regenerated pastures don't emit as much methane, and the methane they do release is absorbed by the soil microbes that live on the stuff.

I am a farmer, cover crops seriously reduce the amount of water in the soul and tillage reduces the soils water holding capacity. The microbes in the soil break down the straw and chaff from the old crop into carbon. This carbon is taken up by the new plant and makes it stronger. The untilled residue acts as a mulch to keep water in over summer. Fertiliser in urea form is just pure nitrogen, this adds biomass which increases carbon intake and leads to more carbon in the soil. Chemicals work in tandem with crop competition, fungi out break and result in huge areas of crop loss of up to 90%. Glyphosate is not applied to crops, it is a weed controller and would kill the crop. It is used pre planting

Great video. Regen ag just makes sense, regardless of its carbon sequestration capacity. I am a farmer, using these practices but I think there is something being ignored - the broken water cycles, large scale and small, especially the small water cycle. Water vapour is a potent greenhouse gas. As lands degrade, in particular with the loss of trees, they become drier. A lot of the lost water ends up in the atmosphere. We need a two-pronged approach: carbon sequestration and water sequestration. Regen ag can rebuild soil carbon. The more soil carbon, the greater the water holding capacity. However, we need perennial systems to maintain healthy water cycles. We need trees! I urge all of us, especially farmers, to look at ways they could incorporate more trees.
By the way, the organic regen ag certification is a terrific idea. It hasn't appeared here in Australia yet but I think it's just a matter of time.

Good video. As a farmer in England, i love the idea of regen farming. Many of the large estates and some smaller producers are already doing it successfully. But its important people understand its not simple for everyone. The use of agri-chemicals and tillage is very hard to live without on some soil types and in some climates. We have a min-till system which is helping to regenerate soils, but we still use minimal chemicals at the moment otherwise we simply wouldn't produce food. Also many of the components of regen agriculture are already present in conventional systems. Ie organic matter going back into soils, compost, cover crops, no-till. We can still be regenerative while using minimal chemicals in order to be productive, as long as they are known to be safe. Regenerative agriculture is the future no doubt, and will do far more for the environment than the current consensus of planting trees, which i might add is a monoculture by itself.

As much as I hate industrial agriculture, I know this is bullshxt when I hear "we could sequester 100% of human-caused emissions". C'mon, 60-70% of anthropogenic C emission comes from fossil deep underground that has nothing to do with soils. And soils cannot continuously soak up carbon forever, it has a maximal carbon capacity. Any attempt to go beyond that (or to achieve high rates of C sequestration in general) would have global tradeoffs (N2O emission for example), although one may be easily deluded by local improvements (ya know, humans are visual animals).

Btw, how is a monoculture field added with compost/manure called regenerative agriculture? This is just simple organic farming, and people have been doing this for centuries.

Just to emphasize this: "regenerative agriculture" is _not_ identical to "organic farming". The former emphasizes the health of the soil and carbon sequestration, the latter avoidance (or hiding) the use of synthetic fertilizers, insecticides and pesticide. The former is sustainable agricultural practice, the latter mostly marketing. (They sometimes _do_ overlap, though.)
Also, it would help if you didn't repeat myths like "conventional agriculture produces less nutritional crops" than "organic farming". There is _no_ evidence for that. The main downside (and a sufficient one) to the conventional farming is soil degradation. Also, use of genetically modified organism is on a "separate axis" from "conventional vs. regenerative farming" one. You can use GMOs in regenerative farming, too.

Agriculture has a very important role to play in the fight against climate change and improving soil carbon sequestration is a key issue. However, it is simply a matter of absorbing as much carbon as a natural grassland or a forest could do (land use change is one of the major causes of global warming), but absolutely not of offsetting all the emissions generated by burning fossil fuels and deforestation. What's more, what we emit into the atmosphere today will remain there for thousands of years, and there is a "delay" effect due to the inertia of the climate (we will only see the effects of our current emissions with a delay of 20 to 30 years). We cannot cancel global warming, we can only limit it on the long term, and this implies a profound change in our lifestyles, in the way we produce, consume, and preserve our environment.

@SKIP AD Um, no. It is not natural to turn our grasslands into deserts, which is what our poor farming practices have done over thousands of years. There is nothing hotter than a desert, and it has no ability to sequester either carbon or water so the air heats up and the water ends up in the oceans instead of on the land where it was before we turned the land into desert. Even if it rains, the water flows off since there is little to no vegetation to absorb it into the soil. If you look at a world map that shows the colors of the planet, you'll see how vast the amount of area is that human beings (yes, not nature) have turned into deserts. If we want to put take CO2 and water, the two main greenhouse gases, out of the air and put the carbon back into the soil as well as the water, we have to use livestock to do it. It's the only thing we can use that can make a big enough difference in re-greening the land. And it will provide nutritious food for people as well once its harvested, gently, of course.
